turn.speaker: patricia_a_millett
turn.label: Ms. Patricia A. Millett
turn.text: --Our position--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --as to the Fourth Amendment requirements?

turn.speaker: patricia_a_millett
turn.label: Ms. Patricia A. Millett
turn.text: --Our position is the Fourth Amendment does not draw a bright line banning seizures, arrests, for civil offenses, such things as deportation, extradition, civil commitment, if a police officer finds someone who is a danger to himself.
There are categories of violations, offenses... I'm not even sure what to call them... civil violations for which arrest has traditionally been recognized to be appropriate.
I mean--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: The issue, if--

turn.speaker: patricia_a_millett
turn.label: Ms. Patricia A. Millett
turn.text: --conveyances and traffic may be another one.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --May I interrupt you?
The issue is not whether arrest may comport with the Fourth Amendment, but arrest without any process issued by a magistrate or some third party.

turn.speaker: patricia_a_millett
turn.label: Ms. Patricia A. Millett
turn.text: Right, and I think the analysis... the mode of analyzing whether proceeding without a warrant or whatever process would be appropriate may be different between criminal and civil cases under the Fourth Amendment.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, didn't the Seventh Circuit rule that the petitioner had waived his argument under the Warrant Clause?

turn.speaker: patricia_a_millett
turn.label: Ms. Patricia A. Millett
turn.text: Yes, they did, Justice... Mr. Chief Justice.
But for purposes of what would be required in the civil arena, our position is, if it's a crime, probable cause justifies an arrest.
You know, probable cause plus.

If it's civil, I think this Court has recognized that under the Fourth Amendment when you get into civil seizures, which take a variety of forms, that a balancing analysis is generally appropriate, and of course we want to--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Every example that you gave involved the risk of absconding or fleeing.
You want to deport someone, extradite someone, there's a high risk that person won't be there if you let them out on the street.

turn.speaker: patricia_a_millett
turn.label: Ms. Patricia A. Millett
turn.text: --That's right, so that's why--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But here we're talking about, I didn't get a license for my business, that my wife got while I was in the police station.
It was that easy.
So when you don't have a breach of the peace, and when you don't have the risk that the person will flee, then what is the justification?
What is the reason for permitting an arrest?

turn.speaker: patricia_a_millett
turn.label: Ms. Patricia A. Millett
turn.text: --I guess I'm... if you're assuming that this is a criminal offense, then... I'm sorry, civil?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I thought we asked you... you were giving examples of civil proceedings--

turn.speaker: patricia_a_millett
turn.label: Ms. Patricia A. Millett
turn.text: Okay.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --where an arrest would be recognized as reasonable, and they were all... fall in the "exigent circumstance" category.

turn.speaker: patricia_a_millett
turn.label: Ms. Patricia A. Millett
turn.text: Right.

I think a balancing would be appropriate in a civil case, and certainly whether or not someone is likely to abscond or... I'm not sure someone who's a danger to himself is the same as a likelihood of absconding, but that could be another factor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Someone about to commit suicide, for example.

turn.speaker: patricia_a_millett
turn.label: Ms. Patricia A. Millett
turn.text: About to commit suicide or other civil... just to harm themselves, if not suicide, but there's going to be a balance--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But this... what's in front of us doesn't seem to fit.
What would be... now, we have... the kind of offense that's involved is failure to get a license to operate some kind of business.
What circumstances would justify an arrest for such an infraction?

turn.speaker: patricia_a_millett
turn.label: Ms. Patricia A. Millett
turn.text: --I think it may be fair for a legislature to... for a legislature or a police department to conclude that as a class there is a... and the Fourth Amendment analysis may permit this, that there is as a class a risk of absconding or injury.

For example, when we think... it's harder to conceive of it in this particular case in the established business, but you'd think of push-carts and vendors along the street who are operating without licenses, and whether in a particular case I know this person, I know where they live, I don't know whether I would be able to find them again, is not the appropriate analysis.
This Court has recognized that at some points when you have an established level of suspicion you need not have--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes, well--
--We're talking about a civil case.
--that's one of the virtues of the Robinson opinion, I say perhaps because I wrote it--
[Laughter]
--that it lays down a flat rule.
Now, you say... are you balancing in every individual case--

turn.speaker: patricia_a_millett
turn.label: Ms. Patricia A. Millett
turn.text: --Well--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --whether you can make an arrest?
That's hardly workable.

turn.speaker: patricia_a_millett
turn.label: Ms. Patricia A. Millett
turn.text: --No, certainly not for crimes.
The question is whether, once it's a civil violation, Robinson wouldn't cover that by its own terms.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: patricia_a_millett
turn.label: Ms. Patricia A. Millett
turn.text: That dealt with a crime.
I mean, it does get complicated because you can have traffic violations that are a crime in one case... Maryland v. Wilson dealt with speeding, where it's a crime.
It is not a civil infraction.
Whren v. United States was speeding and it was a civil infraction.

So it... jurisdiction by jurisdiction the same conduct may, in fact, be either a crime or a civil offense, and I think again when it's... Robinson wouldn't cover it if it's... necessarily if it's civil, but there may be either... either through a balancing analysis or a recognition of historical categories such as conveyances, deportation, immigration control, that they may be the types of civil seizures that are permitted on a... you know, without balancing in individual cases because of... the interests are going to apply generally across the board in making a seizure in those cases to enforce the civil or criminal law, but--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Is it fair to say that you briefed this case on the assumption that we were dealing with a criminal offense?

turn.speaker: patricia_a_millett
turn.label: Ms. Patricia A. Millett
turn.text: --Yes, we did, and I apologize if we don't have a completely thorough analysis of the issue.

We did not read the second question presented to render the first question presented an advisory question, but we certainly are emphatic that there is not a bright civil-criminal line in the Fourth Amendment, that there are classes of seizures, and whether... that are permissible in the civil arena, as I said, deportation, conveyances, or the maritime, or traffic, and whether those--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That's all irrelevant for this case, right?
I mean--

turn.speaker: patricia_a_millett
turn.label: Ms. Patricia A. Millett
turn.text: --I guess it depends on whether this Court reads the second question presented differently from whether we did.
I think it certainly has not been briefed, briefed other than at a very late stage, and it wasn't addressed by the courts below.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --But now we know we are dealing with a civil infraction, so how can we pretend that it's criminal when it's... we're told that it's civil?

turn.speaker: patricia_a_millett
turn.label: Ms. Patricia A. Millett
turn.text: Well, if this Court concludes that it is civil and it needs to address it, then we think it would be better to--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: We don't have to conclude that.
We were told that by Mr. Strauss, that this is in fact in the City of Arlington a civil offense.

turn.speaker: patricia_a_millett
turn.label: Ms. Patricia A. Millett
turn.text: --We think that it may be preferable for this Court to remand to allow a case to come up, or else the courts below to address what either the common law or the practices are for civil arrests on these types of ordinances, which hasn't been briefed and addressed below, and we certainly would be very concerned about having a decision issued without the information provided to this Court that is necessary about civil offenses.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: We should forgive the waiver?
I mean, the point wasn't raised below.
Should we instruct the lower court to give the defendant another... or the plaintiff another swing?

turn.speaker: patricia_a_millett
turn.label: Ms. Patricia A. Millett
turn.text: Well, the Court could certainly dismiss cert as improvidently granted simply on the question that either--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, I thought you were saying we should read the second question, in light of the record, as saying is this particular criminal offense one for which you could arrest someone.
Wasn't that your position, or not?

turn.speaker: patricia_a_millett
turn.label: Ms. Patricia A. Millett
turn.text: --Our position is, we read the second question presented in light of the first question presented.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Which is criminal.
In other words, I take it--

turn.speaker: patricia_a_millett
turn.label: Ms. Patricia A. Millett
turn.text: Right, absolutely.
Absolutely.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --So I take it you're not... I thought... you think we should do the same, I take it, as you did.

turn.speaker: patricia_a_millett
turn.label: Ms. Patricia A. Millett
turn.text: We--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It would be a hypothetical question when we know it is not criminal.

turn.speaker: patricia_a_millett
turn.label: Ms. Patricia A. Millett
turn.text: --If... the Court--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: How can we then say, well, we'll assume that it's waived, that we'll treat something that the city says is civil as criminal?

turn.speaker: patricia_a_millett
turn.label: Ms. Patricia A. Millett
turn.text: --That is the danger that you're essentially issuing an advisory opinion in a case that just does not present the question.
That's again why cert may have--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It's not an advisory opinion in this case if that issue was not raised below.
It's been tried on the assumption that it's criminal.
Why is it advisory in this case?
I, for one, would certainly not send it back to let this new point be dredged up when it was simply foregone in the trial below, so I don't see why it's an abstract case.
I mean, we have a real case before us that's been tried on this assumption, and it seems to me we can decide it on that assumption.
It just doesn't conform to the facts.
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: patricia_a_millett
turn.label: Ms. Patricia A. Millett
turn.text: --I think you were not--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I thought I heard you say that we should dismiss the writ as improvidently granted, because we thought we were dealing with a criminal offense and it turns out to be civil.

turn.speaker: patricia_a_millett
turn.label: Ms. Patricia A. Millett
turn.text: --Our only position... may I answer, Mr.--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: patricia_a_millett
turn.label: Ms. Patricia A. Millett
turn.text: --Our only position is that if the Court wishes to address, or... wishes to address the issue and wishes not to address the criminal issue, that it may... it's certainly within this Court's prerogative to decide that the question it thought it was going to be deciding is not, in fact, now presented to the case in light of the respondent's admissions.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Ms. Millett.
The case is submitted.
